description: From Middle English *lesen, from Anglo-Norman *leser, Old French lesser, laisier (“to let, let go”), partly from Latin laxō (“to loose”) and partly from Old High German lāzan (“to let, let go, release”) (German lassen), cognate with Old English lǣtan (“to allow, let go, leave, rent”) whence let.

entries.meaning: (formal, law) An interest in land granting exclusive use or occupation of real estate for a limited period; a leasehold.
An interest granting exclusive use of any thing, such as a car or boat.
The contract or deed under which such an interest is granted.
The document containing such a contract or deed.
The period of such an interest.
examples: And summer's lease hath all too short a date:

verbs.description: lease (third-person singular simple present leases, present participle leasing, simple past and past participle leased)

entries.meaning: (transitive, formal, law) To grant a lease as a landlord; to let.
(transitive, informal) To hold a lease as a tenant.
examples: I'm leasing a small apartment in Runcorn for a month while I'm there for work.

description: From Middle English lesen, from Old English lesan (“to collect, pick, select, gather”), from Proto-West Germanic *lesan, from Proto-Germanic *lesaną (“to gather”).

verbs.description: lease (third-person singular simple present leases, present participle leasing, simple past and past participle leased) (chiefly dialectal)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pick, select, pick out; to pick up.

description: From Middle English lesen, from Old English lēasian (“to lie, tell lies”), from lēas (“falsehood, lying, untruth, mistake”).

verbs.description: lease (third-person singular simple present leases, present participle leasing, simple past and past participle leased)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, UK dialectal) To tell lies; tell lies about; slander; calumniate.

description: From Middle English lese, from Old English lǣs (“meadow”), from Proto-West Germanic *lāsu (“meadow”). See also leasow.

examples: Since as a child I used to lie
Upon the leaze and watch the sky,
That life would all be fair.

description: From Middle English lesen, from Old English līesan (“to loosen, release, redeem, deliver, liberate”), from Proto-Germanic *lausijaną (“to release, loosen”).

verbs.description: lease (third-person singular simple present leases, present participle leasing, simple past and past participle leased)

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK dialectal) To release; let go; unloose.
The place at which the warp-threads cross on a loom.
